topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554844b5636872684ce80000#post_554844b5636872684ce80000
How he beat Superman? Well he used Kriptonite, simple, but inteand of a rock, Batman used kriptonite dust, so when Superman accidentally inhaled it, all the dust entered in his lugs, making Superman falling sick And almost dying.

Saitama is freaking poweful in planetary levels, but he is not a god and neither inmortal. We don,t know if Saitama can suffer for illness and we don't know if Saitama is inmune to diceases.

So in short, Batman creates a virus for Saitama. Saitama falls sick and gets weak. Batman used this as a chance and beats him.
topics.author: 5239db6da4c72d22d9000358

topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554844b5636872684ce80000#post_554844b5636872684ce80000
This is why I legitimately don't like most superheroes.

"Well my favorite character has less weaknesses!"
"Well my favorite character has no weaknesses!"
"Well my favorite character eventually becomes God!"

I don't like stories where the main character has little to no struggle or such weaknesses.

If you want to know what makes a good superhero watch "Unbreakable"; it may have been a mediocre superhero film by a terrible director, but I still liked it because the villain was a villain not because he was undefeatable but because he was fragile and the hero was the hero not because he was a modern day mythos of a God or such but because no matter how much his body was broken he would get up and it wasn't his body that was unbreakable but it was his determination was unbreakable.

Why is batman so popular?  For the same reason; how many times has he gotten his ass kicked?  How many times has Bane broken his back again?  Why is The Dark Knight considered a modern day classic?  Cause it may not have been the best film ever, but because it was about two characters who would never give up no matter what.  If Heath Ledger hadn't of died then chances are there would currently be a bunch of Batman movies in the work that would be even better.

What makes a good superhero film or series isn't about who has the most super powers but rather seeing the hero no matter how broken get back up.

That is why the Superman movie was utter shit is because the entire time they were talking about how Clark was going to change the world and how he would be a force for good and when he finally does become superman he blows up half of the city, kills hundreds of thousands of people and causes trillions of dollars in damage.

What defines a hero isn't how many super powers he has, rather it's how he refuses to stay down.


Side note: honestly I think superheroes that don't have any super powers or barely has any super powers are far more interesting than characters that have all the super powers.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554849256368722fac1b0800#post_554849256368722fac1b0800
It's not a point on which is a better character.
It's a point if both character were to fight, who would win.

In these kinds of situations, you throw away your fan-feelings, your general rooting for your favourite character and become the third party. You become the dude in the middle and your job is just to observe, not judge.
topics.author: 4fe1b9f47f123b13df002976

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554849256368722fac1b0800#post_554849256368722fac1b0800
IMO, Saitama's a great character because he's very human, He's a superhero mainly for selfish reasons, But he still does it mainly to help people. (And he tends to gives the credit for his achievements to the Non-Godmen for actually putting their lives on the line.)

He's pretty much just a random schmuck who ends up becoming the most powerful man in the world.

He clearly has no chance of winning seeing how the Sea king beat the shit out of various S-classes, But he fights on anyway because he has to. Saitama steps in before the sea king can kill him while he's down and he goes "You did great out there."
